storyInfo: In 1086, as tensions between Babel and the Military Commission escalate, Ascalon chooses her side.

attributes.text: Eight years ago...
Summer, 1086

attributes.content: Residential district, the nomadic city of Kazdel, Kazdel

attributes.text: Remember the promise we made at the beginning of the lesson? Good. Keep your voice low when answering, and don't tell anyone about the classes.
Ray Tanka has been teaching you about our history for the past few months. As for myself, I've been struggling to decide what to teach you in our last lesson.
Mathematics? Language? Agriculture? Weapon-making?
What I've come to realize is that whatever I teach you won't truly change our lives. We've lived silently in despair for too long.
The war eighteen years ago never ended. The ghosts of Leithanien's fleet continue to haunt those who experienced that war.
Many died in despair, drowned in the fear of war and of being consumed by the black rocks that grew from their bodies.
But our instincts drove us to seek a way to overcome despair.
Some declared war on despair, on the outsiders who oppressed us, but they all fell short in the face of cruel reality—

attributes.content: ...Came to see the contracts.
attributes.name: Goodluck

attributes.content: I've never seen a more motivated mercenary than you. Are you trying to buy a mansion in Columbia or something?
attributes.name: Scareye

attributes.content: One should feel lucky just to be alive for so long. In that sense, I suppose your name is well-deserved.
attributes.name: Scareye

attributes.content: I heard a bunch of jobs came in lately. Anything good?
attributes.name: Goodluck

attributes.content: There are eyes on and in the city now. Things didn't turn out too well for the last few who took these jobs.
attributes.name: Scareye

attributes.content: It's Babel stuff. Are you sure you want to be part of that mess?
attributes.name: Scareye

attributes.content: Yeah. I trust my luck.
attributes.name: Goodluck

attributes.content: Have it your way. There's a teacher in town who's been saying good things about Babel's outsiders. Someone is willing to pay to shut him up for good.
attributes.name: Scareye

attributes.content: ...Will do.
attributes.name: Goodluck

attributes.content: I look forward to your surprises.
attributes.name: Scareye

attributes.content: Hope your luck doesn't run out today.
attributes.name: Scareye

attributes.content: The nomadic city of Kazdel, Kazdel
It has been a while since Goodluck came back.
The city has changed a lot. People come and go. He is familiar with the words 'Babel' and 'Military Commission'; there are always people fighting over things that he does not understand.
He does not understand why the Sarkaz feel the need to fight one another.
He takes out the photo of the target, a mild-mannered young man. The triangular marking on his sleeve seems familiar.
A teacher spreading praise about Babel's outsiders, inciting opposition against the Military Commission.
'Sorry, your luck just ran out today.'
Should be around here.
attributes.name: Goodluck

attributes.content: Wait... this place...
attributes.name: Goodluck

attributes.content: He's been away for a long time, but not long enough to forget his home.
Odda's home.
Odda, you should not have gotten involved...
attributes.name: Goodluck

attributes.text: We've gotten used to despair from one defeat after another at the hands of powers beyond our ability to resist.
But we needed to convince ourselves that our despair was not self-inflicted, that it stemmed from an obvious source in our lives.
That is what Babel has become for people in this day and age.
It was Babel who brought the enemies. It was Babel's medicine that worsened our Oripathy. It was Babel's education that sapped our will to resist...
It was Babel who deluded the King of Sarkaz and tricked us into giving up on collecting the blood debt from the outsiders. Babel is the source of all our despair.
I see some of you nodding. No doubt you've heard the same from your parents. In desperate times, people often mistake hearsay for the truth.
But is it the truth, though? Were our lives better without outsiders in Kazdel?
Don't take anything at face value. See, think, and find your own answer.
Yes, it's hard to leave Kazdel. The land outside is full of danger. Even making it to the border of the next country is no small feat.
But I'll still leave this place. I'll go to Leithanien, Columbia, Kazimierz, to anywhere that I may find a way to change things.
Then, I'll come back and teach you, and all the children of the Sarkaz.
What will happen to Babel, you ask? The future of Babel—

attributes.content: Hide yourselves. Don't make a sound.
attributes.name: Odda

attributes.content: Hello? Are you looking for someone?
attributes.name: Odda

attributes.content: Sorry, I got the wrong door.
attributes.name: Ascalon

attributes.content: Do you need help? I'm familiar with the area.
attributes.name: Odda

attributes.content: He smiles. There is no panic in his eyes.
Ascalon scans the sparsely furnished room, and understands.
Do you live here on your own?
attributes.name: Ascalon

attributes.content: Yes...
attributes.name: Odda

attributes.content: My name is Ascalon. I'm from Babel.
attributes.name: Ascalon

attributes.content: Thank you for sheltering him, but you must leave.
attributes.name: Ascalon

attributes.content: Be careful. These are troubled times.
attributes.name: Ascalon

attributes.content: You heard her. Someone knows you're here. You need to go.
attributes.name: Odda

attributes.content: Not just the Military Commission, but also those mercenaries who've been bringing trouble to our doorstep...
attributes.name: Odda

attributes.content: I know. I'm very grateful to you for lending us your house to serve as classroom.
attributes.name: 'Teacher'

attributes.content: The children—
attributes.name: 'Teacher'

attributes.content: I'll take them home. Don't worry, you can continue your classes in a few days, once the storm has passed.
attributes.name: Odda

attributes.content: There will be no need. As I've said before, I'm ready to leave.
attributes.name: 'Teacher'

attributes.content: I've already spent too much time here because I wanted to see the lessons through to the end. There are many places that I still need to see.
attributes.name: 'Teacher'

attributes.content: ...Alright. Oh! Don't forget the potatoes.
attributes.name: Odda

attributes.content: They're from the children and me. It's not much, but they will serve as a few meals on the road.
attributes.name: Odda

attributes.content: Thank you so much... all of you.
attributes.name: 'Teacher'

attributes.content: I should be the one thanking you. I learned a lot from you.
attributes.name: Odda

attributes.content: For the past few years, Kazdel has grown faster than its education and public thinking can keep up.
attributes.name: 'Teacher'

attributes.content: I fear that our powers will be our own destruction, if we do not change the present situation.
attributes.name: 'Teacher'

attributes.content: The conflicts we see in Kazdel now are a good example. This is not how the Sarkaz should be.
attributes.name: 'Teacher'

attributes.content: I have yet to find a way to change all these, but I know that the answer does not lie within Kazdel.
attributes.name: 'Teacher'

attributes.content: Goodbye, Odda.
attributes.name: 'Teacher'

attributes.content: Goodbye... may your journey be safe and smooth.
attributes.name: Odda

attributes.content: Odda watches as the 'Teacher' disappears around the corner, but does not go in.
He does not remember when it started, but he has the habit of sitting by the door, waiting for a familiar someone to return.
Wind stirs the dust from the streets, and the dust stirs up his tears. There is not even a shadow.
He gently closes the door.
Odda...
attributes.name: Goodluck

attributes.content: Goodluck sees the target leave the house. Then, he sees a familiar figure that he has not seen for a long time.
His blade feels heavy. He cannot move.
Odda... I'm sorry... I didn't know...
attributes.name: Goodluck

attributes.content: I'm a lousy dad, but...
attributes.name: Goodluck

attributes.content: He tightens his grip on the knife's hilt.
He knows only one way to give Odda a better future.
...Another one.
attributes.name: Ascalon

attributes.content: A mist shrouds a corpse in the corner of the street, erasing all traces of its existence.
The passing of a life in Kazdel is akin to a speck of dust falling to the ground, unheard, unceremonious, and unnoticed.
His luck has run out.
How long do you plan on hiding there, Manfred? Or are you planning to stab me in the back now?
attributes.name: Ascalon

attributes.content: Another mercenary. How many have you killed?
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: Didn't see the point to keep count.
attributes.name: Ascalon

attributes.content: You could kill one, two, a hundred even, but can you kill every single mercenary who accepts the contract?
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: They just want to remind us that we've been complacent with the status quo for far too long.
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: Using the lives of Babel members as a reminder? To remind whom?
attributes.name: Ascalon

attributes.content: He made a promise to Her Highness. Is this what he calls 'protection' for Babel? All I see are crackdowns on Babel and mercenaries running wild!
attributes.name: Ascalon

attributes.content: There are some things that should not be said aloud. Especially not by you, Ascalon.
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: If you don't like it, arrest me.
attributes.name: Ascalon

attributes.content: Let's see if you've improved at all under his tutelage.
attributes.name: Ascalon

attributes.content: The General has taught me that there are more important things than violence.
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: And by the looks of things, the mercenaries aren't the only ruthless cutthroats around here.
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: Stop dodging if you dare! I'll prove to Their Highnesses that I can beat you!
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: Too slow, Manfred.
attributes.name: Ascalon
Manfred
attributes.content: Wai—

attributes.name: Manfred
attributes.content: Argh!
You're dead. Again.
attributes.name: Ascalon

attributes.content: Ugh...
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: Get up.
attributes.name: Ascalon

attributes.content: Don't... need you... to tell... me...
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: Footwork, Manfred. And Ascalon... stop going for his head all the time?
attributes.name: Theresa

attributes.content: This is the most effective way. It's his own fault for getting hit.
attributes.name: Ascalon

attributes.content: If he can't dodge it, he has to learn to take it.
attributes.name: Ascalon

attributes.content: *sigh*...
attributes.name: Theresa

attributes.content: You're right, Ascalon. But why did you stop? We didn't tell you to.
attributes.name: Theresis

attributes.content: I... I can take it, Your Highness. It's not over yet!
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: Hmph.
attributes.name: Ascalon

attributes.content: Huh? I hit... Your Highness! I hit—
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: Did you, now?
attributes.name: Ascalon

attributes.content: Let me down, Ascalon!
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: Don't hurt him, Ascalon.
attributes.name: Theresa

attributes.content: Manfred's long limbs flail helplessly in the air, while his torso is tied to a wooden stake.
H-How did you do it so fast?!
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: Got my inspiration from the way Her Highness sews.
attributes.name: Ascalon

attributes.content: Manfred wriggles to break free, but the more he squirms, the tighter the ropes hug him.
He cannot understand how Ascalon can be so strong and fast, when she looks as thin and frail as him.
Let—me—down!
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: Look, I won again!
attributes.name: Ascalon

attributes.content: Ascalon raises her weapon high and grins victoriously at the twin sovereigns.
Ascalon has gotten a lot more cheerful.
attributes.name: Theresa

attributes.content: What are you thinking?
attributes.name: Theresa

attributes.content: They're different from the other Sarkaz children.
attributes.name: Theresis

attributes.content: We can change them, but how can we reach all the children of Kazdel?
attributes.name: Theresis

attributes.content: Give me time. Babel can do it.
attributes.name: Theresa

attributes.content: Time is a luxury.
attributes.name: Theresis

attributes.content: I know. But education is not something that can be rushed. What we're doing is leaving hope for the next generation.
attributes.name: Theresa

attributes.content: The flame of hope will never go out, as long as a single teacher in Kazdel remains willing to share with these children the vision of a beautiful future.
attributes.name: Theresa

attributes.content: Theresa casts her eyes towards the two children, full of hope for the future.
Well? Are you going to admit defeat or not?
attributes.name: Ascalon

attributes.content: No! L-Let me down! We're not done!
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: I'll let you down when you admit defeat.
attributes.name: Ascalon

attributes.content: No way!
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: I'll unbind you, Manfred.
attributes.name: Theresa

attributes.content: Thank you, Your Highness... W-woah, why am I flying?! Y-Your Highness!
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: Hehe.
attributes.name: Theresa

attributes.content: ...Hehe.
attributes.name: Theresis

attributes.content: Alright, that will do, Theresa. Let him down.
attributes.name: Theresis

attributes.content: You've improved. But Theresis hasn't taught you everything he knows.
attributes.name: Ascalon

attributes.content: You were always the faster learner, but ever since you left the general, you've been nothing but unadjusted and lost. He is disappointed in your departure, by the way.
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: I may not be as good with words as you are, but at least I don't just ignore the insults against Her Highness Theresa.
attributes.name: Ascalon

attributes.content: Do you really know why Her Highness is so dedicated to Babel's ideals? Do you really know why the General hasn't openly denounced the attacks on Babel?
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: You should have talked to him, rather than turning your back on him.
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: I turned my back? You're the ones who turned your backs on Her Highness and the voices of so many.
attributes.name: Ascalon

attributes.content: It's Theresis who has turned a blind eye to the mercenaries' acts of violence and the damage they've caused Babel! This much I know.
attributes.name: Ascalon

attributes.content: The General has allowed it precisely because he can't ignore the voices of the majority.
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: If the fate of the Sarkaz is doomed to fall into the abyss, what's wrong with using more effective means to prevent it?
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: So that's what you truly think.
attributes.name: Ascalon

attributes.content: It's what most of us in Kazdel think.
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: It's not that I don't trust Her Highness... anyone can promise a better future. But we can't ignore the reality before it.
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: Isn't it crueler to use violence to force a child to shake hands and make peace with the murderer who just killed his father?
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: Say whatever you want.
attributes.name: Ascalon

attributes.content: I'll keep my hands off the Military Commission. But if you try to act through the mercenaries...
attributes.name: Ascalon

attributes.content: Then my job is simple.
attributes.name: Ascalon

attributes.content: No more mercenaries, no more problems.
attributes.name: Ascalon

attributes.content: Ascalon!
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: ...If you have the time.
attributes.name: Ascalon

attributes.content: Go visit Her Highness. I've never seen her so tired.
attributes.name: Ascalon

attributes.content: A puff of mist is the only sign that she was ever there.
Manfred looks down and wipes away the blood slowly seeping out of his chest.
He sighs and turns into the empty street, only to spot the deceased mercenary's effects.
Someday... we will all understand.
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: It was never Her Highness or the General who made the choice.
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: Who's there?
attributes.name: Odda

attributes.content: He hesitates before the door.
It has been a busy day at this old, ramshackle house, from the 'Teacher' to the multiple visitors.
Who could it be outside the door?
Has father finally returned? And if so, what should he say?
He has learned so much from the 'Teacher' that he wants to share with his father, whose visits back home have become less and less frequent.
He takes a deep breath, collects his mind, puts on a calm face, and opens the door.
Hello...?
attributes.name: Odda

attributes.content: Good evening.
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: You're... er, can I help you, sir?
attributes.name: Odda

attributes.content: You know who I am?
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: No sir, but I know the uniform of the Military Commission.
attributes.name: Odda

attributes.content: Just a routine inspection. Do you recognize these items?
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: This is... my father's—!
attributes.name: Odda

attributes.content: There have been some disturbances in the city, and I'm afraid your father... I'm so sorry.
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: Wh-Where did you find them? Was there...?
attributes.name: Odda

attributes.content: There was nothing else left at the scene. I'm sorry.
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: What's your name?
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: ...Odda.
attributes.name: Odda

attributes.content: If you need any help...
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: No... no, I'm very grateful that you brought these back.
attributes.name: Odda

attributes.content: It's been a long time since I last saw him... this is enough.
attributes.name: Odda

attributes.content: I don't have to wait anymore... He's not coming back...
attributes.name: Odda

attributes.content: Do you have family? Or friends you can count on?
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: I can take care of myself. Besides, we see things like this every day in this city, no?
attributes.name: Odda

attributes.content: I-I'm sorry I gushed, sir. I just feel like I know you, somehow...
attributes.name: Odda

attributes.content: I'm sure you're busy. I won't keep you any longer.
attributes.name: Odda

attributes.content: My condolences.
attributes.name: Manfred

attributes.content: The door closes. Manfred can hear the sound of sobbing coming from behind the door, but he doesn't feel sorrow. Not anymore.
Odda's right; he's seen this too many times. Yet he remembers this is not what the city was meant to be.
